summary: An email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney to Colonel Gauger regarding Jeffrey Epstein's work release agreement. The email raises concerns about Epstein's eligibility and the legitimacy of his claimed employment at the Florida Science Foundation, noting discrepancies in the foundation's incorporation date and physical presence.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the work release agreement. The email raises concerns about the truthfulness of his statements regarding his employment at the Florida Science Foundation.

persons.name: Colonel Gauger
persons.context: The recipient of the email, addressed as 'Dear Colonel Gauger.' He is the official with discretion over Epstein's work release decision.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: His office suite is listed as the address for the Florida Science Foundation, which the email suggests is not a legitimate business location.

connections.description: Epstein's claimed work release location is Goldberger's office suite, indicating Goldberger is likely his attorney.
The AUSA is writing to Gauger to provide information and raise concerns about Epstein's work release eligibility.
The AUSA is the prosecutor corresponding about the enforcement of Epstein's plea agreement and work release conditions.

events.title: Meeting regarding Epstein Agreement
events.description: A meeting took place on Tuesday between the Assistant U.S. Attorney and Colonel Gauger to discuss Epstein's agreement.

events.title: Incorporation of Florida Science Foundation
events.description: The Florida Science Foundation was incorporated, contradicting Epstein's claim that it had existed for a 'couple of years' prior to his 2008 plea.

events.title: Change of Plea Hearing
events.description: Epstein stated during his change of plea that he worked at the Florida Science Foundation 'every day' prior to the plea.

locations: 500 S. Australian Ave, Suite 400, West Palm Beach, FL 33401
250 Australian Avenue, Suite 1400, West Palm Beach, FL
keyFacts: The email reveals significant discrepancies in Jeffrey Epstein's claims about his employment for work release, specifically regarding the Florida Science Foundation.
The Florida Science Foundation was incorporated in November 2007, not 'a couple of years' as Epstein claimed during his plea.
The foundation's listed address is Jack Goldberger's office suite, and there is no physical evidence (directory, door signage) or tenant knowledge of the business existing there.
The Assistant U.S. Attorney objects to Epstein's proposed work release, arguing that sitting in his attorney's office making calls and surfing the web does not meet the objectives of imprisonment.
The email shows prosecutorial concern and scrutiny over the implementation of Epstein's controversial non-prosecution agreement and work release terms.
